title: Release Prep

title: refint improve
body:
Fixes #61 and fixes #234 - this rewrites quite a few internals of refint and memberof to make them much more efficient compared to previously. This takes nearly 70s out of the test execution time - a full 25% of the run time of tests.

A number of other improvements have been made through out with regard to memory pre-alloc for hashset/hashmap, fixing some more types, and reducing some un-needed allocations.

- [ x ] cargo fmt has been run
- [ x ] cargo clippy has been run
- [ x ] cargo test has been run and passes

title: 260 entry ava interfaces
body:
Fixes #260 fixes #257 fixes #157. This is really a set of cleanups around the code base to minimise clones, choose better datastructures for specific tasks, improve the ability to pass references in certain calls and more. Generally this just makes everything a bit smoother, and really has big gains on the write path (it's about 20% faster now).

title: 184 151 183 name constraint and spn
body:

This really just does a lot of clean up to make spns more viable. #181 is still outstanding, but you can currently already login via spn a posixid_to_uuid supports this, it's only the resolving of unixgroup/accounts that need to have name as Option to cause a fall back to spn when in a trust.

Cargo.toml. Ref: https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/issues/3931

title: 101 idlcache
body:
Fixes #101, concurrent caching of IDL and Entries. This yields a 10% improvement for test case execution, and 35% for tests run under --release mode. A lot of code around the code base was needed to be touched due to the extra need for mut in some operations and some lifetimes, but the majority of the work was in idl_arc_sqlite.rs, which has the cache layer. There are many performance gains yet to see, but most of those will come through improvement of the concread ARC and it's related BTree implementation.

title: 216 - add initial /status endpoint
body:
This is a stub implementation of 216, adding a `/status` endpoint. Importantly this actually contacts a status thread, which means that the main thread pools aren't affected by this. The idea of the thread pool is that later we can have this thread aggregate statistics and information from the other operation threads that can be displayed in the status.

title: Fix sqlite fails in CI tests and fmt error
body:
Add `libsqlite3-sys` crate to avoid sqlite3 missmatching version.

From [https://lib.rs/crates/libsqlite3-sys](https://lib.rs/crates/libsqlite3-sys)
> If you use the bundled feature, libsqlite3-sys will use the cc crate to compile SQLite from source and link against that. This source is embedded in the libsqlite3-sys crate and is currently SQLite 3.30.1 (as of rusqlite 0.21.0 / libsqlite3-sys 0.17.0). This is probably the simplest solution to any build problems.

Remove sqlite OS packages dependencies for build.

Also, we fix a format error to allow CI tests to pass again.

title: Minor typo and formatting fixes.

title: Add feature for re-adding some group memberships on revival
body:
Implements #49, revive directmemberships if possible on revive. As items that are deleted are able to maintain and preserve their directmembership from MO, this allows a way to back-create group memberships when we revive a user from the recycle bin.

Note that if the group was itself deleted and revived, this breaks the relationship because it causes ref int to remove all the references. This could be a reason to change the refint policy to allow keeping dead-references, but I think I want to think about that more before I change that policy too quickly. 

Saying this, most groups are long lived, we are really wanting to handle the case where you delete and revive a user, or delete and revive a group to restore consistency. Deletenig and reviveng groups and users at the same time will lead to some hairy-complex cases.

title: Add concurrent structures
body:
Implements #10, improve concurrent datastructures.

This replaces the cowcell from concread with bptreemap from concread, which should yield better performance on high throughput situations, especially with schema and acp updates. This is because we no longer copy the full sets on the start of a txn, as the bptree map is able to delay copying *until* we actually commit to a write.

title: acp_enable is optional and non-presence implies true
body:
Implements #88, acp_enable becomes optional. This is important with regard to migrations. When we migrate, if an attribute is present in the migration we always set the value in the case of a single-value attribute (multivalues interleave). This means an admin who may set acp_enable to false on default shipped access controls would have them forcefully re-activated on each server restart. This change makes acp_enable optional, and removes it from the migration. If *NOT* present on an ACP, it's considered "true", so that when an admin overrides this value to false, we will permanently respect that choice.

title: 126 ssh key features
body:
Implements #126 ssh key distribution features. This adds an improved SSH key validator, and the related REST endpoints for SSH keys management due to being a non-trivial type for parsing - we could consider a str -> json instead for future to avoid the custom routines perhaps. This also adds a tool for openssh to consume by the AuthorizedKeysCommand in sshd_config, which gets and lists keys as such:

```
kanidm_ssh_authorizedkeys admin -H https://localhost:8080 -D anonymous -C ../insecure/ca.pem
ssh-ed25519 AAAC3NzaC1lZDI1NTE5AAAAIAeGW1P6Pc2rPq0XqbRaDKBcXZUPRklo0L1EyR30CwoP william@amethyst
```

title: Split read vs write actors
body:
Implements #54 split read vs write actors. Because the database has MVCC/COW properties, only one thread can advance while in a write lock. As a result, we can then split the actors into read vs write handlers so that reads can continue, and writers all end up on one thread. This may have neglible overhead for writers in terms of preparing the transaction etc, but the benefits in cache hot and other things will be much better, as well as allowing a maximal number of readers to remain always unblocked .

title: Implement attribute uniqueness.
body:
Implements #72, attribute uniqueness. This extends schema to have a field "unique" which means a value should be unique for that object, and all other live objects (recycle and tombstones excluded). Note UUID has to retain special handling in base.rs and can't usethis due to needing to check with recycled too..

- [ - ] design document included (if relevant)

title: Docker improvements
body: Improvements to dockefile and update to rust 1.37.

title: 60 authsession gc
body:
Implements #60 authsession garbage collection. If we assume that an authsession is around 1024 bytes (this assumes a 16 char name + groups + claims) then this means that in 1Gb of ram we can store about 1 million in progress auth attempts. Obviously, we don't want infinite memory growth, but we can't use an LRU cache due to the future desire to use concurrent trees. So instead we prune the tree based on a timeout when we start and auth operation. Auth session id's are generated from a timestamp similar to how we'll generate replication csn's. We can then apply a diff that will split all items lower than the csn/sid and remove them from future consideration.

We set the default timeout to 5 minutes. This means that assuming 10,000 auths per second, we would require 3GB of ram to process these sessions before they are expired. We expect any deployment with such large loadings can affort 3Gb of ram :) 

- [ x ] cargo fmt has been run
- [ x ] cargo test has been run and passes
- [ - ] design document included (if relevant)

title: 20190720 system protected
body:
Implements #9 and #1 . This fixes an issue with git incorrectly munging some schema work.

This implements schema class system and object protection, which means that auto-generated types or important system schema can not be affected by mistakes by a user. However, some sub-attributes are able to overriden ie must/may on schema, or account lock on anonymous (not yet implemented).

title: 20190715 dyn schema
body:
Implements #9 - dynamic schema. This allows classes and attributes to be added and modified "live", so that restarts to affect object schema are not required. This is good to allow customisation and other extensions for advanced users, and doing it now makes it "easier" to supply extra schema from the project core into the initialise_idm function.

title: Implement backup, restore and server modes, with configuration args
body:
Implements #11 . This allows backup and restore of the server from the main server binary. Due to the
design of sqlite, backups can be taken while the server is running. Scheduled backups are not yet implemented as part of this feature, due to needing to be able to roll-out old backups.

title: 20190607 authentication
body:
Implements #2 - anonymous authentication.

This is a large PR, but it implements the IdmServer concept ontop of the QueryServer, with account representations. It also adds most of the credential handling framework and concept, fleshes out more of the proto test. Finally, it is the first working implementation of Anonymous authentication, which is limited to the Anonymous account of course. This is important as Anonymous access is required for stateless clients, and due to our design, can easily be limited via acp like any other account.

- [ x ] cargo fmt has been run
- [ x ] cargo test has been run and passes
- [ x ] design document included (if relevant)

title: Implement Access Control Profiles
body:
This implements access controls, including a huge amount of refactor to support
them and their resolution with the "SelfUUID" keyword. Additionally, parts of
the event structure was improved to help, normalised was added as an entry state
and more.

And there are access controls! They work, have tests, and appear sane.

Implements # .

- [ x ] cargo fmt has been run
- [ x ] cargo test has been run and passes
- [ x ] design document included (if relevant)

title: 20190510 access profiles foundations
body:
This is a really large refactor, which lays a lot of group work for access controls. It adds the core access control structure types, it refactors events to take whole entries to allow faster acp matching, and it completely rewrites filters to allow supporting of the SelfUUID resolution via events adding a new filter state "FilterValidResolved". It rewrites filters to be a proper struct, helping to mask and abstract some details. Finally, abstractions for filter generation were added allowing easier rewrites of the filter type in the future, especially because I already know that I plan to refactor these again when it comes to indexing .... 

I may as well have made this commit message "rewrite the whole damn project" because that's what it feels like I did!

- [ x ] cargo fmt has been run
- [ x ] cargo test has been run and passes
- [ x ] design document included (if relevant)

title: 20190508 UUID on entry
body:
Implements #45 and starts #2, #3 and #4. This adds UUID as a proper type on Entries to help make there behavior more consistent and simpler to validate, and this adds the user_uuid to most request and event types, allowing us to identify who is responsible for an operation. This is an important foundational step to access profiles, as we can now at least test their functionality as part of server operations.
